title: Fortran
overview: IBM releases Fortran, the first widely adopted high-level programming language, designed for scientific and engineering computation.

title: Pascal
overview: Niklaus Wirth develops Pascal, a structured teaching language that becomes widely used in academia and early compilers.

title: C Language
overview: Dennis Ritchie develops C at Bell Labs, enabling portable UNIX implementations and becoming one of the most influential programming languages.

title: C++
overview: Bjarne Stroustrup introduces C++, extending C with object-oriented features, later powering system software and large-scale applications.

title: Perl
overview: Larry Wall releases Perl, a flexible scripting language that becomes a staple for system administration, text processing, and early web development.

title: Python
overview: Guido van Rossum creates Python, emphasizing readability and simplicity, later becoming the dominant language for web, data, and AI.

title: Java
overview: Sun Microsystems launches Java with the promise of 'write once, run anywhere', powering enterprise apps, Android, and the web.

title: PHP
overview: Rasmus Lerdorf creates PHP for dynamic web pages, which grows into a major scripting language behind much of the web.

title: JavaScript
overview: Netscape introduces JavaScript as a client-side scripting language, later becoming the backbone of interactive web applications.

title: Ruby
overview: Yukihiro Matsumoto creates Ruby, a language focusing on developer happiness and productivity, later powering Ruby on Rails.

title: C#
overview: Microsoft introduces C# as part of .NET, combining C++ power and Java-like productivity for Windows development.

title: Go Language
overview: Google develops Go (Golang) for simplicity and concurrency at scale, later becoming popular for cloud-native applications.

title: Rust
overview: Mozilla Research creates Rust to offer memory safety without garbage collection, later adopted for systems and browser engines.

title: Swift
overview: Apple launches Swift, a modern programming language for iOS and macOS development, replacing Objective-C over time.
